title: Alfred Mathews
text:
Alfred Augustus Mathews (7 February 1864 – 12 August 1946) was a <a href="Wales">Welsh</a> <a href="Canon%20%28priest%29">priest</a> who was notable as a <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player in his youth; representing Lampeter at club level and playing a single international match for <a href="Wales%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wales</a>.
Biography.
Mathews was born on 7 February 1864. He was educated at <a href="Llandovery%20College">Llandovery College</a> before matriculating to <a href="St%20David%27s%20College%2C%20Lampeter">St David's College, Lampeter</a>. A clergyman by profession, after ordination he was curate, and then vicar of Holy Trinity, <a href="Swansea">Swansea</a> from 1887 to 1897. He became vicar of <a href="Blaenavon">Blaenavon</a> in 1897 and remained in Monmouthsire until his death. He married Ethel Frances, and they had five children, the youngest, Barbara Muriel Mathews was to become <a href="Barbara%20Brooke%2C%20Baroness%20Brooke%20of%20Ystradfellte">Barbara Brooke, Baroness Brooke of Ystradfellte</a>, a British life peer. He died on 12 August 1946.
Rugby career.
Mathews began playing rugby at a young age, taking up the sport as a schoolboy at Llandovery College. He continued playing the sport when he matriculated to St David's. Mathews played only a single game for Wales, when he faced Scotland in the second and final Welsh match of the <a href="1886%20Home%20Nations%20Championship">1886 Home Nations Championship</a>. Played at the <a href="Cardiff%20Arms%20Park">Cardiff Arms Park</a>, Mathews was brought into the team at halfback, replacing captain <a href="Charlie%20Newman">Charlie Newman</a>, and partnered with <a href="William%20Stadden">William Stadden</a> of <a href="Cardiff%20RFC">Cardiff</a>. The game was an important match in the history of rugby, as it was the first international to see the use of the four three-quarter system, brought in by <a href="Frank%20Hancock">Frank Hancock</a>. The game did not go well for Wales and the three-quarter system was abandoned mid-match, which caused further confusion, resulting in a simple Scottish victory. Newman was re-selected to his position for the next season, and Mathews did not represent Wales at rugby again.
Despite an end to his international career, Mathews later joined first-class Welsh team Swansea RFC, and was part of the team that faced the touring <a href="1888%E2%80%931889%20New%20Zealand%20Native%20football%20team">New Zealand Natives</a> in 1888.
